author: By Christopher Clarey
title: WTA Tour Seeks Chinese Inquiry Into Player’s Sexual Assault Accusation
description: The head of the women’s tennis tour asked for a “full and transparent” investigation after Peng Shuai, a player, recently accused Zhang Gaoli, a former vice premier of China, of sexual assault.
content: PARIS — Steve Simon, the chief executive of the WTA Tour, called on Sunday for Chinese authorities to investigate allegations of sexual assault made by the Chinese women’s tennis star Peng Shuai against Zhang Gaoli, a former vice premier of China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Impact of the Browning of America on Anti-Blackness
description: The relative decline of whites in the population does not guarantee racial progress.
content: One of the things I often hear as a person who frequently writes about race, ethnicity and equality, is that the browning of America — the coming shift of the country from mostly white to mostly nonwhite — is one of the greatest hopes in the fight against white supremacy and oppression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: Is America Willing to Tell the Truth About Its History?
description: White Christians should not shy away from the truth about our past
content: I don’t remember the first time I was taught that the Civil War was not fought because of slavery. I am a white Texan, so this idea was simply in the ether, as were myths about “good slave owners” and the “Lost Cause.” I knew that America had a racist history, but when I was a child, the details of what that meant were blurry and vague.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: Conglomerates Break Up
description: First G.E. and then J&J decide to split up their businesses. Inflation is rising. And the Biden administration's vaccine mandate faces court challenges.
content: On Tuesday, General Electric said it will spin off its health care division in early 2023 and its energy business a year later. Only its aviation division will remain. The 129-year-old company’s breakup marks an end to an era of global conglomerates. Other large companies, like Siemens and Honeywell International, have also pared down their businesses over the last few years, and Toshiba and Johnson & Johnson announced last week that they would split up their businesses. But as industrial conglomerates are breaking up, a new breed of conglomerate has emerged: Big Tech companies like Amazon and Alphabet have embraced the strategy of multiple business lines, putting odd bedfellows like books and grocery delivery, or maps and phones, under the same umbrella.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Fromson, Jack D'Isidoro, Dana Lyn, John Woo and Corey Schreppel
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Untold Story of Sushi in America’
description: How a controversial religion from Korea quietly built an empire of raw fish.
content: In 1980, when few Americans knew the meaning of toro and omakase, the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the founder of the Unification Church, spoke to dozens of his followers in the Grand Ballroom of the New Yorker Hotel.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Finality of Our Goodbye Settled Over Me, and My Tears Started to Fall’
description: A sad moment as dusk falls, the right stuff for a cleanup job and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: The U.S. surgeon general says blocking vaccine rules creates a ‘setback’ for public health.
description: The Biden administration’s attempts to compel vaccination for workers at large companies have been met with considerable resistance.
content: Dr. Vivek Murthy, the U.S. surgeon general, said on Sunday that if courts continue to block the Biden administration’s efforts to soon compel large companies to require a Covid vaccine or face weekly testing, it would be “a setback for public health.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Aaron Rodgers returned to the field on Sunday after his Covid-19 isolation.
description: Rodgers faced a mandatory 10-day isolation period after testing positive for the coronavirus. The quarterback has not been vaccinated and has shared baseless claims about vaccines.
content: The Green Bay Packers star quarterback Aaron Rodgers, who was required to spend the last 10 days in isolation after testing positive for the coronavirus on Nov. 3, resumed play on Sunday afternoon against the visiting Seattle Seahawks at Lambeau Field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Austria’s new lockdown will confine the unvaccinated to their homes.
description: The country, facing the biggest surge in virus cases since the pandemic started, is putting strict curbs on the movement of those without shots.
content: Austria will confine unvaccinated adults and minors over age 11 to their homes as part of a targeted lockdown, lawmakers announced Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Kardas-Nelson and Ruth Maclean
title: After Sierra Leone Explosion, a Health System Is Strained
description: Victims are still dying from injuries after a fuel tanker burst into flames last week in Sierra Leone, a country that has no burn units.
content: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — When a fuel tanker exploded in Sierra Leone last week, killing 98 at the scene, the many survivors included a motorcycle-taxi driver who, while stuck in traffic, was engulfed by the fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Climate Deal, Rittenhouse Trial, Pies: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘Dead Among the Living’: Trauma of 2015 Paris Attacks Fills Courtroom
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 14, 2021.
content: “We were ordinary people. We want to be ordinary people again.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Dwyer
title: Casa Magazines Is New York City’s Best Kept Secret. The Secret Is Out.
description: When a writer began reporting a story on Casa Magazines, she had no idea how much admiration the store and its owners had — and how many people would want to speak with her.
content: Last Sunday, I found myself playing phone tag with the Oscar-winning actress Julianne Moore. She had heard I was writing an article about Casa Magazines, a newsstand in the West Village, and called while I was volunteering at the New York City Marathon. We decided via text to speak later in the afternoon, and then her schedule changed. But she was determined to share some kind words about the establishment, which has remained a beacon of a bygone sensibility in an increasingly gentrified neighborhood — and a haven for lovers of print media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: wistful
description: This word has appeared in 163 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: They Warned Their Names Were on a Hit List. They Were Killed.
description: In less than a month, assassins have killed at least eight people in the Rohingya refugee camps of Bangladesh, silencing those who have dared to speak out against the violent gangs.
content: At night in the refugee camps, with only a thin tarpaulin wall as protection, Mohammed waits for the men to come and kill him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Adler-Nissen, Sune Lehmann and Andreas Roepstorff
title: Denmark’s Hard Lessons About Trust and the Pandemic
description: Social and institutional trust are critical when the future is uncertain.
content: Since mid-September, Denmark has tried living as if the pandemic was over. Schools and workplaces are open. Until Friday, you could go to a bar, a nightclub, a restaurant, a movie theater, the gym and sporting arenas without showing proof of vaccination. There was no social distancing or restrictions on large gatherings, even indoors. Face masks are rare in public spaces except airports. The Danish Health Authority’s website plays a rap video thanking all the Danes who are fully vaccinated, which includes 86 percent of people over age 12.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Monika Pronczuk
title: Air Route to Belarus Closed to Migrants in Bid to Halt Crisis
description: Hoping to stem the flow of migrants stuck on the border of Belarus and Poland, Dubai banned Iraqi and Syrian passengers from traveling to Minsk.
content: Dubai on Sunday began banning travelers from Iraq from passing through the emirate on their way to Belarus, cutting off the last major air route from the Middle East to Minsk in an effort to halt a humanitarian crisis that has left thousands of people stranded at Belarus’s border with Poland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: Japan’s Economy Shrinks, but Outlook Is Brighter as Virus Ebbs
description: The coronavirus and supply chain issues stymied growth in the third quarter, but high vaccination rates and low numbers of virus cases point to a recovery.
content: Japan’s economy continued to wobble in the third quarter of 2021, tipping back into contraction, as the country struggled to find its economic footing in the face of coronavirus restrictions and a supply chain crunch that hit its biggest manufacturers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A global climate agreement.
content: On Saturday, diplomats from nearly 200 countries struck an agreement to do more to fight climate change. Signed at the COP26 summit in Glasgow, the pact urged wealthy nations to “at least double” funding to protect poor nations from the hazards of a hotter planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Dozens of N.Y.C. sanitation workers were suspended during an inquiry into the use of fake vaccine cards.
description: It is the latest chapter in the protracted debate over the city’s vaccine mandate for municipal workers.
content: Several dozen New York City workers have been suspended without pay as a part of an investigation into the use of fake vaccine cards at the Department of Sanitation, a city official with knowledge of the investigation said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Six Key Moments That Shaped the Trial of Kyle Rittenhouse
description: Among the important portions of the trial: Mr. Rittenhouse’s own testimony, along with the words of someone who thought he, too, had been shot by Mr. Rittenhouse.
content: KENOSHA, Wis. — The trial of Kyle Rittenhouse has lasted for two weeks, with dozens of witnesses, photo evidence and video clips, as well as testimony from Mr. Rittenhouse himself, who is accused of intentional and reckless homicide and other crimes for fatally shooting two men and injuring a third.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: This or the Chicken
description: Ian Rathkey’s puzzle centers the self.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Ian Rathkey, who is making his New York Times Crossword debut today! He is the 76th constructor to debut in 2021, and he does so with a bright and cheerful Monday puzzle that is sure to send some constructors on nostalgic journeys to their music playing apparatus of choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Afghan College Students Find a New Life, and Safety, in Iraq
description: Regarded as infidels by the Taliban, over 100 students from the American University in Kabul have found an unlikely refuge in the Iraqi Kurdish city of Sulaimaniya.
content: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq — As the Taliban closed in on the Afghan capital, Kabul, in August, what had been a privileged education at the American University of Afghanistan suddenly became a dangerous liability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Yaqoob Akbary and Jim Huylebroek
title: The String of ISIS Attacks That Killed Three Generations of One Afghan Family
description: Over two weeks, the Rajabis suffered loss after loss as suicide attacks on Shiite mosques in two parts of the country ravaged their family.
content: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — When Masooma Rajabi saw her relatives flooding into the family’s courtyard, she broke down in sobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nabil Ayers
title: Why Music Drives Us to Mayhem
description: Generation after generation of young people are drawn to places where they’re pushed, jostled, pummeled or worse. Why do we run into a seething crowd?
content: Antagonistic throngs of metal heads and punks looked ready to collide when my friends and I arrived, a group of high school juniors, at a packed Salt Lake City arena to see Guns N’ Roses. It was 1988, years before the 2000 Pearl Jam concert where nine people died in a stampede, but I knew that people had been crushed to death at a 1979 Who concert and stabbed at a 1969 Rolling Stones concert. So I hung back and watched the band alone that night, as my friends disappeared into the crowd of thousands that pushed up against the stage under a haze of smoke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: How Hanif Abdurraqib Cuts Through the Noise
description: He is a National Book Award finalist for “A Little Devil in America,” but he has more books to write, more projects to take on and more s’mores to research.
content: COLUMBUS, Ohio — He received a MacArthur “genius” grant in September. A week later, he was named a finalist for the National Book Award for his essay collection “A Little Devil in America.” But even though he is grateful for the accolades, Hanif Abdurraqib prefers to stay a bit removed from it all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: What is tromethamine? It is used to stabilize Covid vaccines.
description: Also known as tris, the compound helps maintain the pH of vaccines, extending shelf life at warmer temperatures.
content: When the Food and Drug Administration authorized the emergency use of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine in children ages 5 to 11 last month, the agency noted that the pediatric version would be a bit different than the one for adults: a third the size, with a different buffer for added stability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: How a School District Got Caught in Virginia’s Political Maelstrom
description: Loudoun County tried to address racism and promote diversity within its schools. Then it found itself on Fox News.
content: LEESBURG, Va. — Long before the father was tackled by sheriff’s deputies at the school board meeting, before there was shouting to reopen classrooms and before “parents matter” became the central slogan of the most closely watched campaign in the post-Trump era, Loudoun County was just another American suburbia taking a hard look at its schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Qaddafi Son to Run for President in Libya
description: Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, the former heir apparent of the deposed Libyan dictator Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, filed his candidacy papers on Sunday for the election expected next month.
content: CAIRO — After years underground and months of hints, the son and former heir apparent of the deposed Libyan dictator Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi emerged from the shadows on Sunday to announce that he would run for president in Libya’s coming election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Taxi Explodes Outside Liverpool Hospital, Killing One
description: Three men in their twenties were arrested under Britain’s Terrorism Act several hours after the explosion, in which a second person was injured, the authorities said.
content: Three men were arrested under Britain’s Terrorism Act after a taxi exploded outside a hospital in Liverpool, England, on Sunday morning, killing one person and injuring another, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Gives Ted Cruz His Own Version of ‘Sesame Street’
description: The sketch show, hosted this weekend by Jonathan Majors, also featured a 10-minute performance from the musical guest Taylor Swift.
content: Back in 2012, when the then-Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney professed his affection for Big Bird but nonetheless vowed to cut funding for PBS, “Saturday Night Live” brought in Big Bird himself to explain that he wasn’t a political creature and didn’t “want to ruffle any feathers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bess Kalb
title: Without Parental Leave I Might Be Dead
description: Family leave should be a right, not a privilege.
content: Imagine the following medical hypothetical:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Colorado’s governor says he is ‘frustrated’ with federal regulators about booster eligibility.
description: Federal regulators are considering a request to make all adults eligible for Pfizer-BioNTech’s Covid boosters. Colorado and two other states decided to broaden access anyway.
content: As federal regulators consider a request to expand eligibility of Pfizer-BioNTech’s coronavirus vaccine boosters to all adults, three states decided this past week to broaden access on their own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devin Gordon and Diante Lee
title: Bills End Mike White’s Jets Fairy Tale
description: Are the Jets worth watching? Let’s skip ahead.
content: Our N.F.L. playoffs calculator has an up-to-date look at the latest playoff picture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacey Stowe
title: Donors Withhold Gifts to Protest Changes at Hamptons Sculpture Garden
description: Some patrons of the LongHouse Reserve are upset that its veteran director was let go, but the board says it needed new leadership to expand the garden into a museum with a broader mission.
content: With its clipped hornbeams, lush borders and meandering paths, the LongHouse Reserve is a 16-acre sanctuary on Long Island’s fabled East End, a tranquil respite where visitors enjoy, not just quiet garden views, but sculpture by the likes of Willem de Kooning and Sol LeWitt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Lee Maracle, Combative Indigenous Author, Dies at 71
description: She collected signatures to persuade publishers that people would buy her books. She became a foundational figure in Indigenous literature.
content: Lee Maracle, a writer who chronicled the effect of Canadian settlement on the land’s Indigenous people and the persistence of discrimination, only to find herself in recent years championed by the very cultural and political establishment she had spent her career attacking, died on Thursday in Surrey, British Columbia. She was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: This Revival of Sondheim’s ‘Assassins’ Misses Its Mark
description: The production lacks the power to unsettle despite a fine cast of killers and wannabes who changed, or at least made, history gunning for presidents.
content: The one reliably blood-chilling moment in Stephen Sondheim and John Weidman’s “Assassins” comes courtesy of a killer who is, at best, a footnote in American history: Charles J. Guiteau, the lawyer who shot President James A. Garfield in 1881.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Augustin
title: In Cuba, Desires for Food and Freedom May Spark a Rare Day of Protest
description: Young dissidents who rely on the internet to spread their ideas are calling for a protest on Monday, a bold move with little precedent in Cuba.
content: HAVANA — The line starts during the day and stretches into the night. In the dark before dawn, there are hundreds of people waiting. Four women sleep on cardboard boxes, sharing a thin blanket. Others chat to stay awake. A nurse arrives after a 24-hour shift and takes her place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Climate Promises Made in Glasgow Now Rest With a Handful of Powerful Leaders
description: In Washington, Beijing, New Delhi and beyond, governments face conflicting forces — political, social and economic — that will shape their next steps in the effort to avert a climate crisis.
content: GLASGOW — After two weeks of lofty speeches and bitter negotiations among nearly 200 nations, the question of whether the world will make significant progress to slow global warming still comes down to the actions of a handful of powerful nations that remain at odds over how best to address climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: The Crypto Capital of the World
description: It has to be somewhere. Why not Ukraine?
content: KYIV, Ukraine — A buccaneering 37-year-old educated in a British private school, Michael Chobanian is fluent both in English and the folkways of Ukraine, which he regards as a largely lawless frontier and which he likes to traverse in his black Ferrari 612. He is the founder of Kuna, one of Eastern Europe’s first cryptocurrency exchanges. To him,  his native country is a terrific place to run a business, as long as you have the nerve to navigate a system rife with corruption.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 14, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 14, 2021.
content: An article last Sunday about the renewed popularity of “Attached,” a book on relationship styles published in 2010, gave incomplete credentials for the co-author Rachel Heller. She is a psychologist, not only a writer. The article also misspelled the name of the book’s publisher. It is TarcherPerigee, not TarcherPedigree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Crunch at Ports May Mean Crisis for American Farms
description: Backlogs and cancellations are hitting growers as costs rise, profits slump and overseas customers shop elsewhere.
content: It’s just 60 miles from El Dorado Dairy in Ontario, Calif., to the nation’s largest container port in Los Angeles. But the farm is having little luck getting its products onto a ship headed for the foreign markets that are crucial to its business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Is Brooklyn in the House? Its Politicians Certainly Are.
description: Brooklyn’s influence over New York City politics grew with Eric Adams’s mayoral win, and it could grow further if a candidate from the borough is elected governor.
content: When she took the stage at a recent reception for the Brooklyn Democratic Party, Gov. Kathy Hochul could not ignore the evidence gathered before her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Petra Mayer, Books Editor for NPR and ‘Resident Nerd,’ Dies at 46
description: Ms. Mayer reported on Comic-Con and contributed to Book Concierge, NPR’s literary recommendation tool. She gravitated toward science fiction, romance and fantasy.
content: Petra Mayer, a books editor for NPR and self-described “resident nerd” who delighted readers with her musings about science fiction, comics and cats, died on Saturday at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring, Md. She was 46.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 15, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz and Gabriella Angotti-Jones
title: California’s High School Football Powerhouses Feed the College Game
description: St. John Bosco and Mater Dei, 24 miles apart in Southern California, don’t just funnel players to the top college teams. Increasingly, they resemble them.
content: BELLFLOWER, Calif. — The scent of seared carne asada wafted through the parking lot on a Friday evening last month at St. John Bosco High, an all-boys school tucked in the southeast corner of Los Angeles County.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Víctor Manuel Ramos
title: Three ‘beloved’ snow leopards died of Covid complications at Nebraska zoo.
description: The mountain cats had tested positive for the virus about a month ago.
content: Three snow leopards died of complications related to Covid-19 at a zoo in Lincoln, Neb., despite efforts by staff to restore them to health after they tested positive for the virus about a month ago, zoo announcements said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: ‘Ghost Guns’: Firearm Kits Bought Online Fuel Epidemic of Violence
description: They are untraceable, assembled from parts and can be ordered by gang members, felons and even children. They are increasingly the lethal weapon of easy access around the U.S., but especially California.
content: CHULA VISTA, Calif. — Max Mendoza’s parents awakened just after dawn to the echoing clap-pop of a gunshot, and ran from their bedroom to find their 12-year-old son propped against the couch, eyes wide in pain, terror and surprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Sam Huff, Fearsome Hall of Fame Linebacker, Dies at 87
description: Huff, who became the epitome of the rough-and-tough football star with the Giants, was remembered for his head-on duels with two of the game’s greatest fullbacks.
content: Sam Huff, the Giants’ Hall of Fame middle linebacker who became the face of pro football, his feats celebrated in the national news media when the N.F.L. began to vie with major league baseball as America’s No. 1 sport, died on Saturday in Winchester, Va. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Queen Elizabeth Misses Remembrance Service Because of Sprained Back
description: The British monarch, 95, has put off multiple trips and engagements recently, and the latest cancellation has deepened anxiety about her health. She has now been out of sight since mid-October.
content: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II has sprained her back, Buckingham Palace said on Sunday, forcing her to miss a remembrance service that she had planned to attend after canceling multiple trips and other engagements over the past month because of poor health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nana Asfour
title: Etel Adnan, Lebanese American Author and Artist, Dies at 96
description: Her novel about a kidnapping in Lebanon has become a classic of war literature. She was in her 80s when her art started to draw international attention.
content: Etel Adnan, an influential Lebanese American writer who wrote a seminal novel about the Lebanese civil war and achieved acclaim in her later years as a visual artist, died on Sunday in Paris. She was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: At Least 1 Dead After Quakes Strike Southern Iran
description: Two moderate temblors hit Hormozgan Province on Sunday afternoon, state TV reported.
content: At least one person died after two moderate earthquakes struck Hormozgan Province in southern Iran on Sunday afternoon, state television reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Baylor Punctures Oklahoma’s College Football Playoff Hopes
description: The Sooners faced a 7-2 Baylor team that they’d beaten seven consecutive times. But instead of capturing a needed win, Oklahoma took a 27-14 loss.
content: It is rare that a Power 5 team’s undefeated record works against it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Storm Brings Hail and Strong Winds to New York Region
description: A fast-moving storm caused heavy rains, quarter-size hail and powerful wind gusts in New York City, New Jersey and Long Island. The storm prompted rare tornado warnings in the region.
content: A fast-moving storm caused heavy rains, quarter-size hail and powerful wind gusts in New York City, New Jersey and Long Island. The storm prompted rare tornado warnings in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Do some pre-Thanksgiving housework. It will pay dividends.
content: Good morning. We’ll get to recipes in a moment, delicious ones for a week of eating, but we’ve got housework to do beforehand, in advance of this coming Thanksgiving feast. Call me bossy if you like, but the labor will pay dividends, I promise.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Do Religion and Science Clash or Coexist?
description: Faith and science; a cheer for New Yorkers; the culture factor in politics; exploiting the cosmos; religious exemptions for vaccines.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
